content.description: A face climb using two columns, finishing on Fist Date (5.8) to the right.
content.protection: trad gear or top anchor bolts.

climbs.name: Throw it Back
climbs.fa: Tim Kosderka, Wayne Burns, and Don Myers, 1977.

content.description: 2nd crack left of the Dime. Refer to Rock Climbing Western Oregon, Vol. 2: Umpqua 2007, topo pages 253-254.
content.protection: trad gear of bolted top anchors
content.location: Right side of the pillars. Refer to Rock Climbing Western Oregon, Vol. 2: Umpqua 2007, pages 249-256.

content.description: Crack to the right of Twin Sister. Refer to Rock Climbing Western Oregon, Vol. 2: Umpqua 2007, topo page 252.
content.location: Refer to Rock Climbing Western Oregon, Vol. 2: Umpqua 2007, pages 249-256.

content.description: Another must do climb if you are visiting Youtklut Pillars. Easily toproped. Refer to Rock Climbing Western Oregon, Vol. 2: Umpqua 2007, topo page 253.
content.protection: trad gear or bolted top anchors
content.location: Center of Youtlkut Pillars. Refer to Rock Climbing Western Oregon, Vol. 2: Umpqua 2007, pages 249-256.

content.description: Good large pro, a mix of face climbing, offwidth, crack and layback, and sustained to the top.
content.location: Center of the tallest set of pillars.  Walk off the back.

content.description: Chiquapin has a variety of off-width and fist size crack moves. It is a popular route at the pillars. Top anchors are easily accessed from a scramble trail coming in from the side. Largely in the shadows and requires some maintenance at the beginning of each season. Refer to Rock Climbing Western Oregon, Vol. 2: Umpqua 2007, topo page 252.
content.location: Refer to Rock Climbing Western Oregon, Vol. 2: Umpqua 2007, pages 249-256.

climbs.name: Almost Polock
climbs.fa: Tim Kosderka, Wayne Burns, and Don Myers, 1977.

content.description: This is one of the classics at the pillars, but requires some maintenance at the beginning of each season. Refer to Rock Climbing Western Oregon, Vol. 2: Umpqua 2007, topos pages 252-253.
content.location: Center of the pillars. Refer to Rock Climbing Western Oregon, Vol. 2: Umpqua 2007, pages 249-256.

content.description: Refer to Rock Climbing Western Oregon, Vol. 2: Umpqua 2007, topo page 254.
content.protection: trad gear or bolted top anchors.
content.location: Right side of the pillars. Refer to Rock Climbing Western Oregon, Vol. 2: Umpqua 2007, pages 249-256.

content.description: Short bolted face climb to the left of Chinquapin Crack.
content.location: Left side of the Pillars. Refer to Rock Climbing Western Oregon, Vol. 2: Umpqua 2007, pages 249-256.

climbs.name: 3D Crack
climbs.fa: D. Campbell, D. Vanslyke, D. Gildark, 1994.

content.description: A crack climb that varies from 5.8 to 5.10+ depending on if you stay in the crack or not. Refer to Rock Climbing Western Oregon, Vol. 2: Umpqua 2007, topo page 252.
content.location: Refer to Rock Climbing Western Oregon, Vol. 2: Umpqua 2007, pages 249-256.

content.description: Youtlkut (Yu klut) Pillars is a 180-foot high formation of columnar dacite. There is easy class-4 access using a very steep scramble trail around the left side (looking up) of the pillars. Bolt anchors without chains have been placed in a short headwall on top which is set back about 6 feet from the edge of the columns. Establishing a topropes requires lots of webbing or cordelette. The pillars receive afternoon sun. They are above 4400 feet so the area is typically snowed in until June or later. The pillars provide for fun but sharp columnar face and crack climbs. Refer to Rock Climbing Western Oregon Vol 2: Umpqua 2007 pages 249-255. There's a bathroom and trails have been built. No-fee camping within the old growth timber across the road from the pillars.
